title: 106_hr728
content:
The Act titled "Small Watershed Rehabilitation Amendments of 2000" allows for the rehabilitation of water resource structural measures constructed under certain Department of Agriculture programs. This includes the rehabilitation of structural measures near, at, or past their evaluated life expectancy under the Watershed Protection and Flood Prevention Act. The "Small Watershed Rehabilitation Amendments of 2000" Act allows for the rehabilitation of structural measures in water resources projects to extend their service life and meet safety standards. This includes protecting, correcting damage, upgrading, and addressing deterioration of structural components. The "Small Watershed Rehabilitation Amendments of 2000" Act covers water resource projects that involve rehabilitation of structural measures to meet safety standards, including protection, correction of damage, upgrading, and addressing deterioration of structural components. The act also allows for decommissioning structures if requested by the local organization. The Food Act of 1981 allows for cost share assistance for the rehabilitation of structural measures, such as dams, originally constructed as part of a covered water resource project. The Secretary may provide financial assistance to cover a portion of the total costs incurred for the rehabilitation project. Total costs include expenses for land acquisition and all components of the rehabilitation project. The Food Act of 1981 allows for cost share assistance for rehabilitation projects, covering land acquisition, easements, rights-of-ways, administration, technical assistance, contracting, and construction costs. Federal funds can cover up to 65% of total rehabilitation costs, not exceeding 100% of actual construction costs. Local organizations are responsible for securing necessary land rights and permits. The Secretary may require proper zoning regulations for rehabilitation projects to prevent inadequate development and maximize benefits. Technical assistance is available for watershed project rehabilitation through the Natural Resources Conservation. The Secretary, through the Natural Resources Conservation Service, can offer technical assistance for rehabilitation projects upon request from local organizations. This assistance includes specialists in various fields. Rehabilitation assistance cannot be used for operation and maintenance activities specified in agreements between the Secretary and local organizations. Operation and maintenance responsibilities remain with the local organization. The Secretary can renegotiate agreements with local organizations for operation and maintenance responsibilities after rehabilitation of water resource projects. Local organizations can apply for technical and financial assistance for rehabilitation from the Secretary, subject to approval by the State agency or Governor. The Secretary can request the State dam safety officer to be involved in the application process for rehabilitation of structural measures. The Secretary will establish a system for approving rehabilitation requests based on availability of funds and equitable treatment for all local organizations. Natural Resources Conservation Service personnel may assist in preparing applications for assistance. The Secretary will establish a system for approving rehabilitation requests based on availability of funds and equitable treatment for all local organizations. The Secretary may not approve a rehabilitation request if the need is due to a lack of maintenance. Authorization of appropriations for financial and technical assistance is provided for fiscal years 2001-2005. The Secretary, in collaboration with State agencies, will assess rehabilitation needs for water resource projects nationwide. A database will track project benefits and expenditures, with annual reports submitted to Congress. Grant recipients must report on completed projects within 90 days of assistance. The local organization receiving assistance must report to the Secretary on the status of any rehabilitation efforts funded under this section. TITLE II--DAM SAFETY

SEC. 201. DAM SAFETY. The Secretary of the Army will create an inventory of dams built with specific funds and assess their rehabilitation needs. A report on the inventory and assessment must be submitted to Congress within 2 years. If necessary, interim actions will be taken by the Secretary. The Secretary of the Army will assess dams funded with specific funds for rehabilitation needs and submit a report to Congress within 2 years. If a dam poses a significant risk to public safety, the Secretary can take interim actions to prevent or mitigate the risk, with a 65% federal cost share. $25,000,000 is authorized for appropriations for this purpose, with a limit of $5,000,000 per dam. Assistance is not available for dams under the Department of the Interior's jurisdiction. The Secretary of the Army will coordinate with State dam safety officials and the Director of FEMA in carrying out the assessment of dams funded for rehabilitation, with a limit of $5,000,000 per dam. Passed the House of Representatives on July 17, 2000.
